member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap
member.summary: A bitmap is a 2D grid of pixels that form an image.

example.p: To load and draw a bitmap, first add a to your XAML page.
Add the image files you want to display (png, jpeg, etc.) to your Visual Studio project, and make sure their Build Action is set to Content.
In the page implementation class (eg. MainPage.xaml.cs), declare fields to hold the bitmaps:
Use the CreateResources event to asynchronously load the bitmaps:
Use the Draw event to display them:

member.name: P:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap.Dpi

member.summary: Creates a CanvasBitmap from an existing Direct3D graphics surface.

remarks.p: The bitmap's properties are determined by the properties of the surface. If the surface is able to be used as a render target then a CanvasRenderTarget instance is actually returned. However, to avoid needing to cast, use .
This will use the default (96) DPI.

The value of AlphaMode is determined by the pixel format of the surface. If the surface supports alpha, then the AlphaMode is set to CanvasAlphaMode.Premultiplied, otherwise it is set to CanvasAlphaMode.Ignore. See Pixel Formats for more information about which formats support which alpha modes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap.GetPixelBytes
member.summary: Returns an array of raw byte data for the entire bitmap.

ul.li: Works on bitmaps of any format.

For uncompressed texture formats, the size of the array is SizeInPixels.Width * SizeInPixels.Height * (bytes per pixel). The number of bytes per pixel is determined by . For a CanvasBitmap with the default format of DirectXPixelFormat.B8G8R8A8UIntNormalized this is 4.
For block compressed texture formats, the size of the array is SizeInPixels.Width * SizeInPixels.Height * (bytes per block) / 16. See Bitmap block compression page for more information.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap.CopyPixelsFromBitmap(Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap)
member.summary: Copies the entire bitmap specified into this bitmap, at position (0, 0).

remarks.p: The bitmap specified must be able to fit, and the pixel formats must match.
It's an error to copy a bitmap onto itself.
This method is most efficient when both bitmaps were created from the same CanvasDevice, but is also able to copy between bitmaps of different devices.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap.CopyPixelsFromBitmap(Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies the entire bitmap specified into this bitmap at the point specified.

remarks.p: The bitmap specified must be able to fit, and the pixel formats must match. The destination point is specified in pixels (not DIPs).
It's an error to copy a bitmap onto itself.
This method is most efficient when both bitmaps were created from the same CanvasDevice, but is also able to copy between bitmaps of different devices.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap.CopyPixelsFromBitmap(Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmap,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Copies the specified region of a bitmap into this bitmap, at the point specified.

remarks.p: The region must be able to fit, and the pixel formats of the two bitmaps must match. The destination point and source region are specified in pixels (not DIPs).
It's an error to copy a bitmap onto itself.
This method is most efficient when both bitmaps were created from the same CanvasDevice, but is also able to copy between bitmaps of different devices.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat
member.summary: This denotes the format used when saving a bitmap to a file.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.Auto
member.summary: The actual encoding used is determined from the file extension. If the file extension is not recognized, an error is reported.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.Bmp
member.summary: Indicates Windows Imaging Component's bitmap encoder.
member.remarks: This file format doesn't support different quality levels. Different values for 'quality', if specified, will produce the same result.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.Png
member.summary: Indicates Windows Imaging Component's PNG encoder.
member.remarks: This file format doesn't support different quality levels. Different values for 'quality', if specified, will produce the same result.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.Jpeg
member.summary: Indicates Windows Imaging Component's bitmap JPEG encoder.
member.remarks: This format supports the selection of a quality level, between 0.0 and 1.0. Quality 0.0 will produce a low quality image with a small file size. Quality 1.0 will produce a high quality image with a large file size.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.Tiff
member.summary: Indicates Windows Imaging Component's TIFF encoder.
member.remarks: This file format doesn't support different quality levels. Different values for 'quality', if specified, will produce the same result.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.Gif
member.summary: Indicates Windows Imaging Component's GIF encoder.
member.remarks: This file format doesn't support different quality levels. Different values for 'quality', if specified, will produce the same result.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Graphics.Canvas.CanvasBitmapFileFormat.JpegXR
member.summary: Indicates Windows Imaging Component's JPEGXR encoder.
member.remarks: This format supports the selection of a quality level, between 0.0 and 1.0. Quality 0.0 will produce a low quality image with a small file size. Quality 1.0 will produce a high quality image with a large file size. This format is called Windows Media Photo (WMP) in some documentation.
